channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.N. Cases Read Like ‘Manual in How Not to Investigate’ Sexual Assault
item.media:description: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, has promised to make accountability for sexual misconduct a central part of his leadership.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: The secretary general has vowed greater accountability for sexual misconduct. But many employees say that won’t end decades of sexism and abuse within the organization.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE

item.title: E.U. Reaches Deal on Migration at Summit, but Details Sketchy
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and Alexander Gauland of the far-right party Alternative for Germany, right, at the Parliament in Berlin on Thursday. Representatives of his party heckled her during her speech.
item.description: After talks in Brussels that lasted all night, leaders agreed in principle, at least, on how to shore up their external borders and create screening centers for migrants.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Far-Right Cell Plotted Attack on French Muslims, Authorities Say
item.media:description: Police officers near the home of a man suspected of being the leader of a far-right extremist group on Monday in Tonnay-Charente, France.
item.description: Ten members of a group that said it was “fighting the Islamic peril” face terrorism charges. Guns, ammunition and explosive material were seized.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Beijing Dispatch: Mao 101: Inside a Chinese Classroom Training the Communists of Tomorrow
item.media:description: Students watching Feng Wuzhong’s online lecture video during a course on Mao’s ideology at Tsinghua University in Beijing.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: Ideological classes have long been a part of the college curriculum in China. But they are more important than ever to the Communist Party, even if many students say they are numbing propaganda.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Helsinki Summit Meeting Is Set for Trump and Putin
item.media:description: President Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin met on the sidelines of a Group of 20 meeting in Germany in 2017.
item.description: President Trump will meet President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Finland on July 16, a politically delicate time with the midterm elections approaching.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and EILEEN SULLIVAN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: South Korea Must Offer Alternatives to Military Draft, Court Rules
item.media:description: Activists and conscientious objectors during a rally outside the Constitutional Court in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday.
item.description: The country has jailed hundreds of conscientious objectors every year, mostly Jehovah’s Witnesses. Now such men will be given the option of civilian service.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Australian Law Targets Foreign Interference. China Is Not Pleased.
item.media:description: Australia’s attorney general, Christian Porter, told Parliament that the new laws represented the most significant counterintelligence overhaul since the 1970s.
item.description: Though government officials have said they are not aimed at any country, the laws have passed at a moment when Australia is especially anxious about Chinese power.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: Thailand Cave Rescuers May Drill to Reach Soccer Team
item.media:description: Rescue workers at the Tham Luang Cave complex in Thailand on Thursday, where boys from a youth soccer team and their coach have been trapped since Saturday.
item.description: As the frantic search for a youth soccer team entered its sixth day, U.S. Air Force specialists joined the efforts, and water continued to be pumped out.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and RYN JIRENUWAT

item.title: China’s Biggest Movie Stars Get a Pay Cut (From the Government)
item.media:description: The Chinese authorities issued rules on actors’ pay after Fan Bingbing, one of China’s biggest stars, was accused of trying to dodge taxes.
item.description: Officials said limiting actors’ pay would help curb tax evasion and celebrity worship. But the government also wants to make China’s film industry a force abroad.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY

item.title: China Taps the Brakes on Its Global Push for Influence
item.media:description: Chinese construction workers in Colombo, Sri Lanka, in early June. New governments in places like Malaysia and Sri Lanka have questioned why their predecessors borrowed so much from Beijing.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Chinese companies are steering less money into its Belt and Road Initiative, as top officials ask whether borrowers will be able to repay loans.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: U.K. Fears for Its Beer and Crumpets. Blame a Carbon Dioxide Shortage.
item.media:description: As England progressed to the knockout stage of the soccer World Cup, brewers, bars and pubs were closely monitoring supplies of carbon dioxide.
item.description: Lower supplies of the gas mean that beer loses its fizz and some meat can’t be packaged. That could affect the supply of some staples of British summers.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Migration Agency Picks a New Leader, and Sends Trump a Message
item.media:description: Ken Isaacs was forced to withdraw his candidacy to lead the United Nations migration agency, tainted by his own track record and President Trump’s migration policies.
item.description: The International Organization for Migration will be led by António Vitorino, after Ken Isaacs, the American nominee, withdrew because of a lack of support.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: A Toronto School Where the Kindergartners Speak 40 Languages
item.media:description: Students from Stephanie Hammond’s kindergarten class during their learning activity time.
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.description: There are so many children in one Toronto neighborhood that the school board built an entire school just for kindergartners — 24 classes.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Thailand Cave Rescue Mission Will Continue, Prime Minister Tells Families
item.media:description: Rescue workers inside Tham Luang Cave in Thailand’s northern province of Chiang Rai, on Friday. A youth soccer team and their coach have been trapped there for six days.
item.description: The search for 12 boys and their soccer coach trapped behind rising floodwaters has become a national focus, with the king following events closely.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and RYN JIRENUWAT

item.title: The Saturday Profile: From Jewish Saint, to Israeli Pol, to Diaspora’s Ally
item.media:description: Natan Sharansky in Jerusalem. The rights activist and former Israeli cabinet minister is retiring as head of the Jewish Agency at age 70.
item.media:credit: Corinna Kern for The New York Times
item.description: At 70, Natan Sharansky is reflecting on his life and career. “You never finish anything,” he says. “You do your part, and then you let others continue.”
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Update: With Ban Upheld, Travel Industry Urges a Welcome for Tourists
item.media:description: Venezuela is one of the countries affected by the travel ban.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Travel to the United States has declined after President Trump’s initial executive order. Now, after a Supreme Court ruling, companies are emphasizing their commitment to hospitality.
item.dc:creator: ELAINE GLUSAC

item.title: Maryland, Supreme Court, Russia: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Letter 64: ‘Somewhere in Australia,’ Explained
item.media:description: An archival copy of The New York Times from 1942, with one of many stories carrying the dateline “Somewhere in Australia.”
item.description: Digging into the New York Times archives, I discovered a heart-wrenching story about a former Australia correspondent from World War II.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Israeli Judge Convicts Man on Charges of Threatening U.S. Jewish Groups
item.media:description: Michael Ron David Kadar, seated, was convicted in Israel on Thursday of making threats against Jewish organizations in the United States.
item.description: The judge said the man, a dual American and Israeli citizen, made thousands of threats, including against numerous Jewish organizations in the United States.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: French Cement Giant Lafarge Indicted on Terror Financing Charge in Syria
item.media:description: The Lafarge cement plant in Jalabiya, Syria, in February. A panel of French judges is examining whether Lafarge and some former executives violated international sanctions by paying the Islamic State and other armed groups to keep operating.
item.description: In a rare move, French authorities charged Lafarge SA, one of France’s biggest companies, with financing the Islamic State and endangering the lives of its employees.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Captured on Video, Jogger Is Elusive After Pushing Woman Into Traffic
item.description: The identity of the man who shoved a 33-year-old pedestrian into the path of a bus will probably remain a mystery, as the authorities said all leads had been exhausted.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Chartered Plane Crashes in Mumbai, Killing at Least 5
item.media:description: Wreckage at a construction site in Mumbai, India, where a chartered plane crashed on Thursday.
item.description: A turboprop aircraft out for a test flight crashed into a construction site, killing everyone on board and at least one pedestrian.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Britain Abetted U.S. Torture of Terrorism Suspects, Parliament Finds
item.media:description: The headquarters of the British Secret Intelligence Service, in London. In hundreds of cases, a report from a committee of Parliament says, agents knew or suspected that detainees were abused, but did not object.
item.description: A four-year investigation by a committee of Parliament found hundreds of cases in which agents knew or suspected that detainees were abused, but did not object.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Mattis, in South Korea, Affirms ‘Ironclad’ Alliance Despite Halt to Drills
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and his South Korean counterpart, Song Young-moo, upon his arrival on Thursday at the Defense Ministry in Seoul.
item.description: The defense secretary reaffirmed the United States’ commitment to its ally as Washington and Seoul plot a path after the Trump-Kim summit meeting.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Fire at Nairobi Market Kills at Least 15
item.media:description: The Gikomba market, in the center of the Kenyan capital, has been damaged several times by fire. The cause of the blaze on Thursday has not been established.Credit
item.description: The blaze broke out in a timber yard around 2:30 a.m. and spread through a market, apartments and shanties in the center of the Kenyan capital.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Mexican Soccer Fans’ New Champions: The South Korean Squad
item.media:description: South Korean consul general to Mexico, Byoung-Jin Han, celebrating with grateful Mexican fans outside the Korea embassy in Mexico City, Mexico, Wednesday.
item.description: Germany’s World Cup loss meant Mexico would live to fight another day — and fans had South Korea to thank.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY and SU-HYUN LEE

item.title: Shanghai Knife Attack Kills Two Schoolchildren
item.media:description: Flowers were left on Thursday for the victims of a knife attack outside an elementary school in Shanghai. Police say a man with a knife attacked three boys and a mother, killing two of the boys.
item.description: Mass shootings are rare in China, but children are sometimes targeted in knife attacks on schools.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: As Cameroon English Speakers Fight to Break Away, Violence Mounts
item.media:description: A market in Bamenda, Cameroon, last November after a homemade bomb exploded overnight.
item.description: Some of the Central African country’s Anglophones want to found a country called Ambazonia. The French-speaking government is deeply opposed.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Dutch Lawmakers Approve Partial Ban on Burqas and Niqabs
item.media:description: A woman wearing a burqa walked past the Palace of Justice in The Hague in 2014. The Dutch parliament’s Upper House approved on Tuesday a partial ban on face coverings in some public areas, a spokesman said.
item.description: The law, approved by the Dutch parliament’s Upper House on Tuesday, also bans ski masks and helmets, but it would directly affect some Muslim women.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER and LIAM STACK

item.title: Other Countries Forge Ahead on Crypto Regulations
item.media:description: The Blockchain Summit took place in April in Zug, Switzerland. “Switzerland is already developing into a leading hub, and I think that will be even more the case in the future,” said Olga Feldmeier, chief executive of Zug-based SmartValor.
item.description: While the United States lags, Switzerland, Singapore and Britain have become leaders in setting guidelines.
item.dc:creator: LAURA SHIN

item.title: A Victory for Coral: Unesco Removes Belize Reef From Its Endangered List
item.media:description: A section of reef off the coast of Belize. The government has imposed a moratorium on oil exploration in the area.
item.media:credit: Todd Winner/Stocktrek Images, via Science Source
item.description: The Belize Barrier Reef has been removed from the United Nations list of threatened world heritage sites because it no longer faces immediate danger from development.
item.dc:creator: TRYGGVI ADALBJORNSSON
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: U.N. Reports Sharp Increase in Children Killed or Maimed in Conflicts
item.description: The United Nations annual report says more than 10,000 children were killed or maimed in armed conflicts in 2017.
item.dc:creator: SATOSHI SUGIYAMA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: China and Russia Move to Cut Human Rights Jobs in U.N. Peacekeeping
item.media:description: United Nations peacekeepers from Uruguay on patrol in Ituri Province in the Democratic Republic of Congo in March.
item.media:credit: Diana Zeyneb Alhindawi for The New York Times
item.description: The demands to eliminate the jobs come as the United Nations is struggling to complete its peacekeeping budget and Washington is also pressing the body to lower spending.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Supreme Court, Disney, Unions: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Rescue Ship Docks in Malta as 8 Nations Agree to Take Its Migrants
item.media:description: An Italian Coast Guard vessel approaching the MV Lifeline rescue ship in the Mediterranean last Thursday.
item.description: An agreement to distribute the migrants over several countries came a day before a European Union meeting on the issue. Germany will not to take any in.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: China Won’t Yield ‘Even One Inch’ of South China Sea, Xi Tells Mattis
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis with his Chinese counterpart, Gen. Wei Fenghe, in Beijing on Wednesday.
item.description: Disagreement over the contested sea and Taiwan are major issues as the American defense secretary meets the Chinese leader in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: O.P.C.W., Chemical Weapons Watchdog, Gets Power to Assign Blame
item.media:description: Britain’s foreign secretary, Boris Johnson, said the ability to assign blame for chemical weapons use “is crucial if we are going to deter the use of these vile weapons.”
item.description: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons voted on Wednesday to make the change, a move opposed by Russia and Syria.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons

item.title: Moroccan Protest Leader Is Sentenced to 20 Years in Prison
item.media:description: Demonstrators held pictures of Nasser Zafzafi, the leader of the Rif region's protest movement, during a protest in May.
item.description: Nasser Zefzafi led massive demonstrations touched off by the 2016 death of a poor fishmonger in Morocco’s Berber Rif region.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: E.U. Leader Warns of ‘Worst-Case Scenarios,’ Citing Trump
item.media:description: Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council, in London on Monday. He said in a letter to the heads of government of the European Union that “unfortunately the divisions go beyond trade” with the United States.
item.description: Donald Tusk, head of the European Council, warned leaders that there were deep divisions in the trans-Atlantic relationship as a trade war loomed.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Hills Ablaze Above Manchester as U.K. Wildfire Rages for 4th Day
item.media:description: Wildfire swept across the moors near Manchester, England, on Tuesday.
item.description: Firefighters sought military help to fight a blaze across seven miles of countryside on the edge of one of England’s most populous urban areas.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Sudan Won’t Execute Woman Who Killed Husband After Reported Rape, Lawyer Says
item.media:description: Noura Hussein
item.description: Noura Hussein had her sentence reduced to five years in jail for stabbing and killing her husband, whom she was forced to marry when she was 16.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A Peace Deal for South Sudan Is Signed. Will It Last?
item.media:description: From left: South Sudan’s former vice president, Riek Machar; President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda; President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan; and President Salva Kiir of South Sudan in Khartoum, Sudan, on Monday.
item.description: The president of South Sudan and his former vice president signed a peace deal in a bid to end their country’s protracted civil war.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Trump and Putin Will Hold Summit Meeting, Officials Say
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, with John R. Bolton, President Trump’s national security adviser, on Wednesday at the Kremlin.
item.description: The gathering has worried some European allies, who fear it could overshadow a NATO summit meeting and President Trump’s visit to Britain in mid-July.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Facebook Halts Aquila, Its Internet Drone Project
item.media:description: Facebook had sought to beam internet access to remote areas with the help of drones. But the project has been abandoned.
item.description: The company had envisioned a fleet of solar-powered aircraft that would help bring more people online in remote parts of the world.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: Poland’s Holocaust Law Weakened After ‘Storm and Consternation’
item.media:description: Israeli flags were carried between the former death camps of Auschwitz and Birkenau during a Holocaust remembrance march in April.
item.description: Poland, seeking to repair a diplomatic rift with allies including the United States and Israel, amended a law that critics said stifled free speech.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: As Search for Thai Boys Lost in Cave Hits Day 5, a Nation Holds Its Breath
item.media:description: Soldiers relaying electric cable deep into the Tham Luang cave in Chiang Rai, Thailand, on Tuesday.
item.description: A dozen boys and their soccer coach, trapped in a flooded cave complex since Saturday, are the focus of a huge rescue operation and the hopes of a watching country.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and RYN JIRENUWAT

item.title: In Hong Kong, Where Guns Are Rare, Deadly Shooting Shocks Residents
item.media:description: A woman believed to have shot four people on Tuesday was arrested at a nearby mall in Hong Kong. An 80-year-old woman and a 62-year-old man were killed.
item.description: Gun crimes are exceptionally rare in the city, and the shooting of four people, two fatally, has dominated front pages and news broadcasts.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY
